p: A substantial fraction of biomass nitrogen can be volatilized during pyrolysis, predominantly as N 2 (ref. 69). The nitrogen remaining in BC typically has negligible availability 70. Therefore, no value was assumed for BC as a nitrogen fertilizer. Up to a maximum of 100% of biomass phosphorus and potassium was assumed to remain available in the BC. The low end of the sensitivity range for phosphorus and potassium fertilization value was set at zero, to represent situations in which combustion ash from a BES might be used to provide an equivalent nutrient value to BC. At the high end, lignocellulosic feedstocks of straw, wood or bagasse contain up to 800 mg P kg −1 and 9,000 mg K kg −1 (95% confidence) 68. Nutrient use efficiency can be approximately 20% lower for organic than mineral fertilizers 71 72, therefore, we base nutrient values on 80% of the equivalent prices of phosphorus in Ca(H 2PO 4) 2 (triple super phosphate) and potassium in KCl. We use the 2005–2014 price ranges of $220–860 Mg −1 triple super phosphate and $180–650 Mg −1 KCl (ref. 73).
